text: hi this is Tanya from the publication
team at MIT opencourseware I'd like to
show you a course called toy product
design in this class students work in
small teams to design and prototype new
toys all of this takes place in the MIT
toy lab which was founded in 2004 by
Professor David Wallace I worked with
graduate student Barry cudgerowitz on
this course site he developed and
teaches the class
in the project section you'll see all of
the things students have developed let's
take a look at 2006 where the theme was
toys to promote good dental hygiene
here's r2d tooth he's the work of the
red team
they call it the ultimate robotic dental
hygiene sync top assistant
you can see that R2 holds a lightsaber
toothbrush that lights up when you use
it
students worked with mentors from a
local toy company and a dental hygienist
from MIT medical to develop their ideas
they also visited students at a local
school to get feedback on their
preliminary designs
the theme for 2007 was toys that could
be inexpensively manufactured in Brazil
here's Eggman and Friends a collection
of six egg-shaped tops that have a
special power when you spin them such as
singing each egg comes in a special egg
carton with a lightning bolt lock
of course it's not all just fun and play
in addition to working in the toy lab
students attend lectures and complete
reading assignments to learn about
things like ergonomics and safety
half of the total grade is based on
individual work and the other half is
based on teamwork
each team has to come up with three
sketch models then select two for
mock-up designs
finally each team takes one of its ideas
all the way to completion
students are provided with many
resources to guide them and stimulate
ideas and we've included them on the
site
at the end of the course students
present their prototypes at the
playsentations an event where they
present their work to toy designers
Engineers elementary schools children
and the MIT community
by the way ocw's site for toy product
design can be downloaded for use offline
the link and instructions are right here
I enjoyed working on this course and I
hope you'll enjoy exploring it
foreign
you can explore more courses like this
one at
ocw.mit.edu or get email updates from
MIT opencourseware by subscribing to our
monthly newsletter we hope you'll help
us keep going and growing by making a
donation at
ocw.mit.edu donate
